front.title: A Well-Known Sinkhole for the Internet

abstract.t: A common method for dealing with unwanted traffic is to direct that traffic at nominated addresses within a network that are null-routed; that is, packets with such destination addresses are discarded silently by routers with a null route for that destination configured. These addresses are colloquially known as sinkholes, by analogy with the same term used in Physical Geography to describe a hole in the ground formed by some form of collapse of the surface layer, into which objects may fall and be lost forever.

This document describes an Internet-scope anycast sinkhole service with associated well-known, permanent IPv4 and IPv6 address assignments, and provides guidance both for network operators and for those wishing to use the service to discard unwanted traffic efficiently.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: A common method for dealing with unwanted traffic is to direct that traffic at nominated addresses within a network that are null-routed; that is, packets with such destination addresses are discarded silently by routers with a null route for that destination configured. These addresses are colloquially known as sinkholes, by analogy with the same term used in Physical Geography to describe a hole in the ground formed by some form of collapse of the surface layer, into which objects may fall and be lost forever.

It is common practice for network operators to configure such sinkholes on many or all of their routers in order to avoid the cost of transporting packets across a backbone only for them to be discarded. This configuration is, in effect, a network-scope, anycast sinkhole service. The addresses used for such sinkhole services are typically assigned from address pools administered by the network operator, and are for internal use.

This document describes an Internet-scope anycast sinkhole service with associated well-known, permanent IPv4 and IPv6 address assignments, and provides guidance both for network operators and for those wishing to use the service to discard unwanted traffic efficiently.

section.title: Existing Facilities
section.t: Network-scope sinkholes are in widespread use as destinations for remote-triggered black holes , . The addresses of the sinkholes used for these purposes are generally specific to the network operator that deployed them, and are not published.

describes IPv6 addresses assigned for the purpose of discarding traffic. Those addresses are not intended to be used across autonomous-system borders, however; they are not observed to be generally "reachable" and are frequently the subject of martian filtering .

section.title: DNS Provisioning
section.t: The IANA is further requested to arrange reverse DNS for all individual addresses assigned in . All addresses should map to the name SINKHOLE.ARPA. The name SINKHOLE.ARPA should map to the lowest addresses assigned for each address family.
The following approach is suggested. The IANA is free to choose other approaches.

list.t: The zone SINKHOLE.ARPA should be provisioned on suitable nameservers as described in . A delegation for SINKHOLE.ARPA to those nameservers from the ARPA zone should be provisioned.

The reverse zone or zones for the assigned IPv4 and IPv6 addresses should be provisioned on suitable nameservers as described in . Suitable delegations for those zones should be provisioned from their parents.
All zones should be signed with DNSSEC parameters of the IANA's choosing, and all delegations should be secure.
